title: nullius
author: nullius
content: A.For years, I have had many questions raised about my possible usage of alternate pseudonyms. Â Some are possibly true; some are definitely false. Â As a matter of personal policy, I refuse to answer any of them: Â I neither admit nor deny. Â I do not acknowledge my alternate pseudonyms, unless I have a positive reason to do so; and I do not deny alt accusations that are actually false.When I have done nothing wrong, there is no reason for me to invade my own privacy by admitting to the ones that are true. Â If I were to deny any of the ones that are false, I reasonably expect that I would then be accused of lying about itâ€”indeed, I would be placed in a classic Kafkatrap whereby denial is taken as evidence that the accusation is true. Â And selectively admitting or denying some would reduce my anonymity set for others, by process of exclusionâ€”in essence, by partition-attacking myself in the manner further described below. Â The wisdom of my policy is well-considered.B.This forum was founded by a pseudonymous cypherpunk Tor user, who called himself â€œSatoshi Nakamotoâ€. Â However, the forum has accreted a self-appointed clique of vigilantes who delight in hunting for real or imagined alternate pseudonyms. Â They demand answers to questions they have no proper cause to askâ€”and in the manner of an inquisition, they accuse people of dishonesty for any answer other than a confession.Denial means that you are lying. Â Refusal to answer equates to denial, which means that you are lying. Â Ignoring all questions on grounds of none of your business equates to lying. Â The bare fact of using an alt results in accusations of being a so-called â€œfake newbieâ€, even when no attempt is made to pretend that one is an actual newbie.My own experience has left me wondering: Â What would happen, if â€œSatoshi Nakamotoâ€ were to attempt returning to his own forum under an alternate pseudonym?To avoid any suspicion that he was a so-called â€œfake newbieâ€, he would need to play dumb about Bitcoinâ€”thus rendering any engagement here a waste of his time and energy. Â It would probably be obvious that he was a knowledgeable Bitcoiner, with long experience. Â Those who relish outing pseudonyms and violating othersâ€™ privacy would give him no peace.He would surely be harassed with alt accusationsâ€”many alt accusations, many of them false. Â He would be unable to deny any of them: Â Denying the false ones would set him up so that if he were ever asked, â€œAre you Satoshi?â€, then refusal to answer would be an admission. Â And ultimately, he would be unable to avoid ever giving even the slightest suspicion that he may be Satoshi. Â He would be the same actual person, with the same style and the same substance. Â It would probably just be a matter of time before he was hit with that dread question, â€œAre you Satoshi?â€, or with public speculation that effectually outed him.Satoshi could not afford to risk it.C.In 2020, a high-profile forum member suddenly vanished: Â Lauda said goodbye.There has been some unreasonable speculation that she may return under an alternate pseudonym. Â There have even been some ridiculously stupid assumptions that she must. Â This has left me wondering: Â What would actually happen, if she were to try it?First, she would be tagged as a â€œfake newbieâ€. Â There would probably be demands that she disclose her â€œmain accountâ€. Â And she could not reliably conceal the style and substance of her personality. Â She attained fame as Lauda, because she has a unique character and rare abilities. Â If she were return under another name, she would still have the same character and the same abilities.Not if, but when someone sooner or later suspected her of being who she actually is, clueless idiots and trolls would demand that she acknowledge being Lauda. Â If she refused to answer, then she would be accused of dishonestyâ€”of dishonestly denying what she neither admitted nor denied.It is likely that she would also be accused of being other people who, in fact, are not her. Â She could not deny those accusations, either: Â If she were to deny them, then her real identity could be discovered by process of elimination. Â It is a bruteforce partitioning attack: Â Accuse someone of being everyone they could plausibly, or even not-quite-imaginably be, and then see which accusation she doesnâ€™t deny.Why ruin oneâ€™s own privacy by destroying oneâ€™s own anonymity set? Â It is very foolish to deny false alt accusations. Â Tenfold so, when truthful denials are also stereotypically met with accusations of lying. Â Any policy other than â€œneither admit nor denyâ€ is shooting oneself in the foot.Yet even if she took a firm â€œneither admit nor denyâ€ stand to all questions, it is probable that sooner or later, she would nonetheless be outed as Lauda. Â And then, she would also be falsely accused of dishonesty for refusing to admit or deny that she was Lauda. Â Until then, she would be accused of dishonesty for refusing to admit or deny false accusations connecting her to random accounts.She could not afford to risk it.D.Some discussion venues have an administrative policy forbidding more than one account per individual person. Â The policy is of arguable value; its merits depend on the particulars of the venue. Â In some cases, it may make sense. Â Here, it wouldnâ€™tâ€”here, on a forum founded by a pseudonymous cypherpunkâ€”here, on a forum where the administrator has sometimes banned people for doxing him in violation of forum rules. Â This forum has a high expectation of privacy, and an explicit tolerance of NEWNYM.An administrative restriction of one account per individual is entirely different than a self-appointed clique of vigilantes, who feed their own egos by trying to out people for no reason.For the most part, the latter are also hypocrites. Â Most of them operate under a pseudonym. Â Some of them claim that alternate pseudonyms should be explicitly acknowledged. Â But they themselves neither disclose nor acknowledge their â€œreal lifeâ€ identitiesâ€”and they probably donâ€™t disclose their forum pseudonyms to people who know them by their â€œrealâ€ names. Â Moreover, it is reasonable to presume that most of them probably have alternate pseudonyms in other Internet venues, which they do not disclose here.The word â€œpseudonymâ€ literally means â€œfalse nameâ€ (< ÏˆÎµÏ…Î´ÏÎ½Ï…Î¼oÏ‚, < ÏˆÎµÏ…Î´Î®Ï‚ + á½„Î½oÎ¼Î±). Â For anybody who ever uses a pseudonym without full disclosure of identity, it is dishonest to criticize the use of multiple unacknowledged pseudonyms.Some critics of pseudonymity do not commit this dishonesty. Â For example, Vod openly publicized his â€œreal nameâ€ and physical location; he doxed himself on his own website, linked from his forum account. Â I disagree with Vod on this issue, for other reasons; but at least, he was honest and consistent in his opinion about it. Â Those who do not self-dox are self-serving hypocrites when they unreasonably pry into othersâ€™ use of multiple pseudonyms.Regardless, everyone who is categorically opposed to unacknowledged multi-account pseudonymity creates a culture that forbids Satoshi from returning to his own forum.E.Do you wish that Satoshi should be able to return to his own forum under an alternate identity? Â If you imagine that he has, then you have not considered the realities described aboveâ€”but do you dream that he should be able to, if he is still alive?Embrace privacy culture!Donâ€™t ask questions about othersâ€™ pseudonyms, much less demand answers, unless there is is a strong reason such as evidence of fraud based on the usage of multiple identities.Do not thoughtlessly speculate with a total lack of discretion. Â If you must chortle to yourself over what you suspect is some neat little discovery, at least have the decency to be subtle about it. Â I do as I say, here: Â I have noticed some things I kept quiet about, and only discreetly inquired out of curiosity in PM if e.g. someone outed his multiple pseudonyms on a different forum.Make reasonable use of alternate identities yourself. Â And donâ€™t abuse them: Â Do not sockpuppet, scam, troll, or evade bans! Â Do not buy and sell accounts, which is the conveyance of false reputation. Â Just feel free to compartmentalize your public activities according to the subject matter: Â Pick a new name, hit the NEWNYM button, and make yourself a new forum account. Â This is life in cypherspace: Â It is the cypherpunk way.Have a health problem you want to discuss? Â Confused by an abusive relationship with a manipulative psychopath? Â Suffered a very embarrassing financial wipeout with a margin account? Â Got a harmless but unusual kink? Â Want to talk altcoins, without being insulted and ridiculed by your buddies in the Wall Observer? Â (Now, thatâ€™s kinky!)More importantly: Â Do you have solid evidence of wrongdoing by a DT member? Â Not dumb trolling with bare accusations, much less with empty insults: Â Evidence. Â On a forum where the â€œDT gangâ€ is real, and shooting the messenger is customary, bringing a strongly-evidenced accusation against a DT member is more controversial than all but the most marginalized political opinions.Most importantly in principle: Â Do you have any controversial opinions?This is privacy culture and freedom of speech:Quote from: theymos on August 28, 2012, 09:17:31 PMI don't have a problem with alt accounts as long as they're not used for evading bans. If you're hesitant to say something controversial because you don't want it to be associated with your name, please create an alt account and say it.Italics are theymosâ€™.Do it for yourself. Â Do it on principle. Â And do it for Satoshi.It is useless and meaningless to say that anyone who suspects a Satoshi sighting should keep quiet. Â The only theoretical possibility for Satoshiâ€™s secret return is a social norm, a community nomos, that makes it taboo to speculate on alternate identities or â€œmain accountsâ€ without adequately strong reasons for asking.If we had such a strict taboo here, then maybeâ€”just maybe Satoshi could risk popping up with an alt account for a little chit-chat with us. Â Of course, we would never know it; the whole point is that we would never know it. Â But at least, such a thing would be possible.As it stands, it is impossible. Â Satoshi would only try creating an alt here, if he were a total fool. Â Satoshi was not a fool. Â Therefore, I am morally certain that Satoshi has no alt accounts here on the forum that he founded.And thatâ€™s sad.SAD. ğŸ˜¿

comments.body: Local rules:Â  Moderated at my discretion.Â  I have in my AI settings a censorship dial that goes all the way from â€œfree speech absolutistâ€ to â€œliterally Fascistâ€; I may feel like turning it up here.Â  Needless to say, permabanned users are permabanned.A tangential addendum:Â  In OP, I linked several times to posts by or about an account that some people allege is my alt.Â  Thus, although reputational issues are off-topic here, and I will nuke from orbit any inappropriate discussion thereof, I should reinforce my message in OP with a few words about why I linked to those postsâ€”why most of all, I made sure to link to those posts.Per the policy that I have consistently upheld for years, I neither admit nor deny the allegation that I am death_wish.Â  It is nobodyâ€™s business if I am.Â  If I am not, it would be impossible for me to not to have discovered the account through the numerous public accusationsâ€”plus one PM from a Legendary account, with a gently implied question about this.Either way, I did think it exemplary for the message in OP here.Â  I have therefore linked several times to death_wishâ€™s posts for an excellent example of why people may want unacknowledged alt accounts, as disconnected from their â€œrealâ€ fake-names as their â€œmain accountâ€ fake-names are from their dox.Â  Never forget that â€œpseudonymâ€ literally means â€œfake nameâ€.I have also had some fun with the issueâ€”then laughed all the more, and issued negative trust feedback, after a possibly delusional, definitely malicious habituated liar accused me of deleting a post thatâ€™s still there.Â  It is the classic Big Lie technique.Anyway, my point hereby is this:Â  I believe in privacy.Â  I am quite resolute about that.Â  I think itâ€™s funny that a bunch of degenerate gossip-mongers believe they can coerce me to admit I am he.Â  And it would be funnier if Iâ€™m not.Â  If not, then on principle of privacy, I will gladly take the troll-attacks for some poor sod who wrecked himself on margin, lost his bitcoins, then publicly humiliated himself by venting and weeping and wailing in the presumed safety of a throwaway account.Didnâ€™t I always tell people not to buy BTC on margin?Â  Why, yesâ€”yes, I did!Has my life been perfect?Â  Assuredly not.Is yours?Â  I will guess no.Â  Have you never done anything that you regrettedâ€”which hurt only yourselfâ€”for which you took full responsibilityâ€”about which you just wanted to talk?In a thread that is primarily about Satoshi and pseudonymity, this is the inverse of â€œwe are all Satoshiâ€:We are all death_wish.

I guess it's different because if I ever leave (or come back with different user) not many people will realize or even care.I remember this always happened even in IRC days though. Nicks would suddenly disappear or reappear or even get taken over and people pretended to be others etc. But from my own view, I don't understand or agree that this culture happens. OR if it's culture it only affects those who do get involved in forum business. I think many more are like me only involved in the topical discussions, Trust and Spam report at a basic level. It never comes to my mind to identify the person behind a username.

Â Outside that context, I neither admit nor deny that it is mine.)The creator of that account obviously wanted to keep it anonymous, and was clearly using an alt account in good faith to discuss issues of public importance.Example B: Â death_wish. Â In May of 2022, a Newbie account posted in the Wall Observer about his getting wrecked on leverage. Â He made no attempt to hide his being an experienced Bitcoiner, and an experienced user of the Bitcoin Forum. Â He strongly implied having experience with the Wall Observer; he named WO regulars whose advice he sought.There soon ensued some thoughtless speculation that he is I. Â They smeared â€œnulliusâ€ every way they couldâ€”they even affirmatively claimed, without any evidence, that he (allegedly I) was lying about his margin liquidations, for reasons I cannot fathom. Â N.b. that D.W. made it excruciatingly clear that he was not seeking any kind of financial assistance.So thoroughly did that clique associate that account with me in the public mind that a supposedly pro-privacy user blatantly addressed death_wish as â€œnulliusâ€. Â (Note to self: Â Be skeptical of BlackHatCoiner on privacy issues.)The creator of that account obviously wanted to keep it anonymous. Â He was clearly using an alt account in good faith to discuss issues of personal importance to himâ€”and explicitly to warn newbies about the dangers of margin accounts, as he said many times. Â His very first post contained a graphic entitled â€œobject lessonâ€.I have never admitted or denied the allegation that I am death_wish; and in his entire post history thus far, death_wish has never admitted or denied being me. Â I do like to rub it in the faces of the anti-privacy canaille that they have no power to force me to answer that question either way. Â Neener-neener. Â I have seen several accounts that were not mine accused of being nullius alts, by the same group of DT members. Â I cannot identify the accounts, without breaching my â€œneither admit nor denyâ€ policy: Â I can only identify accounts with neither admission nor denial, or deny unidentified accounts.Whereupon, I reiterate: Â If I have such troubles, what would Satoshiâ€™s risk be? Â Millions of people around the world are eager for a Satoshi sighting. Â He could not afford the risk.
